I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

        

1. 
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  a  proposed 
equity investment of up to $15 million in Mekong Brahmaputra Clean Development Fund, L.P. 
The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 

II. 

BACKGROUND AND RATIONALE 

A. 

Economic and Sector Background 

2. 
Aggressive  development  throughout  Asia  has  put  substantial  pressure  on  the  region’s 
resource  base  and  has  strained  the  buffering  capacity  of  the  environment.  Unhampered 
extraction of carbon-based fossil resources such as coal and oil to meet the region’s expanding 
energy needs has added to the release of greenhouse gases (GHGs) that contribute to global 
climate  change  and  harm  the  environment.  This  development  path  will  need  to  be  balanced 
over the long term with more sustainable alternatives.  
 
3. 
Despite  rapid  development,  many  developing  member  countries  (DMCs)  of  the  Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  do  not  have  affordable  power  for  large  portions  of  their  populations 
because energy investment cannot keep up with demand. Some DMCs in the Greater Mekong 
Subregion (GMS)1 and in South Asia,2 whose energy sectors are less developed than those of 
their peers, obviously need attention. Because of policy, financial, and technical limitations, they 
have  not  achieved  their  vast  potential  for  clean  energy  resource  development  and  clean 
technology  use.  Investing  in  a  clean  energy  sector  fund  that  would  provide  more  capital  to 
alternative  energy  and  environment  sector  projects  in  the  region  would  help  overcome  the 
financial limitations.  
 
Investment  in  clean  energy  projects  in  these  target  DMCs  is  low  primarily  because 
4. 
(i) energy policy frameworks do not adequately support or encourage clean energy projects, and 
(ii) the countries have limited financial and technical expertise in this sector. On the policy side, 
ADB’s  public  sector  departments  have  been  proactively  addressing  and  working  with  the 
country  governments  in  the  GMS  and  South  Asia  through  regional  cooperation  strategies  and 
programs.  But,  especially  given  the  DMC  governments’  limited  resources,  the  private  sector 
must  also  mobilize  funds  for  energy  as  institutional  and  regulatory  reforms  are  made.  To 
achieve  energy  security  the  public  and  private  sectors  should  thus  complement  each  other  in 
investing in clean energy in the target DMCs. The private sector can efficiently mobilize funds 
for the sector through various means, including long-term private equity. 

1. 

Greater Mekong Subregion 

The  GMS  Economic  Cooperation  Strategy  and  Program 3   for  energy  foresees  a 
5. 
competitive regional market that facilitates the optimal development and use of the subregion’s 
energy  resources,  contributing  significantly  to  economic  development  and  reducing  poverty.  4 
The development of regional power trade will enable the GMS countries to lower power costs, 
stabilize  supply,  and  reduce  GHG  emissions.  The  GMS  program  also  looks  forward  to  wider 
cooperation in the energy subsectors, including  alternative energy sources such as renewable

and  clean  energy,  to  strengthen  energy  security,  energy  efficiency,  and  the  sustainable 
development of energy resources. 
 
6. 
Another  component  of  the  program  is  increased  and  sustained  investment,  from  both 
local and outside sources, through cooperative efforts. In support of this goal, (i) the institutional 
framework for investment promotion will be strengthened; and (ii) development partners and the 
private sector, within and outside the subregion, will be encouraged to invest in the GMS. 
 
7. 
A significant portion of the population of the GMS still has no access to modern forms of 
energy.  In  2008,  24%,  or  about  70  million  people,  had  no  access  to  electricity.  Eighty-three 
percent  of  all  households  in  Cambodia,  80%  in  the  Lao  People’s  Democratic  Republic 
(Lao PDR),  and  over  50%  in  Viet  Nam  still  use  wood  for  fuel. 5  Clearly,  sustainable  energy 
investments must increase in the target countries. 

2. 

South Asia 

8. 
The statistics for the South Asian countries are often worse. Most of these countries lag 
behind  in  energy  sector  development,  despite  their  significant  (but  underdeveloped)  natural 
resource  potential.  In  Nepal,  only  48%  of  the  population  in  2007  had  access  to  electricity  and 
other  modern  forms  of  energy.6  Institutional,  technical,  and  financial  limitations  constrain  the 
development of its rich hydropower resources. 
 
9. 
In Bangladesh and Bhutan, half of the populations lack access to electricity. The policies 
and  institutions  in  these  two  countries  are  weak  but  are  being  strengthened  with  the  help  of 
multilateral  organizations  such  as  ADB,  the  United  Nations,  and  the  World  Bank  Group.  In 
Bangladesh, ADB is supporting policy and institutional reforms to improve the efficiency of the 
energy,  transport,  education,  and  other  infrastructure  sectors  that  are  critical  to  sustainable 
development.7  Bhutan,  for  its  part,  is  striving  to  improve  its  policies  to  increase  private  sector 
participation  (especially  foreign  direct  investment)  in  hydropower  and  other  renewable  energy 
development.8 

B. 

Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations 

1. 

Consistency with Strategy 2020 

ADB’s Strategy 20209 provides a context within ADB’s primary goal of poverty reduction 
10. 
in the region for (i) all member countries to become low-carbon economies over the long term to 
mitigate  the  effects  of  climate  change,  and  (ii)  those  countries  to  attain  energy  security  while 
sustaining  economic  development  through  the  use  and  expansion  of  clean  energy  sources. 
While the public sector has a major role in realizing these objectives, Strategy 2020 also looks 
forward  to  the  greater  participation  of  the  private  sector.  The  strategy  thus  provides  for 
increased support for private sector business activities in sustainable clean energy.

2. 

Consistency with Subregional Strategies 

11. 
The  GMS  and  South  Asia  in  particular  will  need  more  private  sector  investment  to 
complement the limited public sector spending on sustainable energy infrastructure. The GMS 
subregional  cooperation  business  plan, 10  together  with  other  GMS  documents,  sets  a  clear 
agenda for clean energy programs in the GMS countries. The Energy Strategic Thrust I under 
the GMS program of action in the medium term11 refers to broader energy cooperation through 
improved  energy  security  and  sustainable  resource  development,  including  subregional 
cooperation  in  renewable  energy.  The  objectives  of  the  GMS  program  for  the  energy  sector 
were  expanded  in  the  GMS  midterm  review  to  include  the  development  of  alternative  and 
renewable sources of energy, energy efficiency, and energy security.12  
 
12. 
The goals and programs defined in the regional cooperation operations business plan for 
South  Asia13  also  involve  increasing  energy  investments  and  improving  the  energy  mix  in  the 
subregion with a bias toward renewable sources. Among the five key operational objectives of 
ADB’s strategy for South Asia14 are cooperation in energy and private sector participation.  

3. 

Consistency with Country Strategies 

The  proposed  investment  is  broadly  aligned  with  the  country  strategies  for  the  various 

13. 
countries to be targeted by the fund. Examples of this are as follows: 
 
Cambodia.  In  its  country  operations  business  plan,15  Cambodia  is  concerned  mainly 
14. 
with using the GMS cooperation program to pursue its renewable energy development agenda, 
particularly to widen access to energy through rural electrification. The strategy also fosters the 
active participation of the private sector in the various hard infrastructure investments that must 
be made, particularly in agriculture and energy, for a sustainable future. This complements the 
public  sector's  various  interventions  in  improving  access  of  the  population  to  reliable  and 
affordable power supply.  
 
15. 
Nepal and Bangladesh. According to the midterm review of Nepal’s country partnership 
strategy6,  inefficiency,  unpredictability,  and  lack  of  transparency  and  accountability  in  key 
energy  service  institutions  are  the  main  impediments  to  energy  sector  development.  For 
Bangladesh,  the  challenges  are  similar.  Thus,  in  these  two  countries  ADB  assistance  will  be 
directed  at  improving  governance  and  efficiency  in  the  power  sector  and  encouraging  private 
sector  participation.    This  also  supports  the  public  sector's  initiatives  to  improving  rural 
electrification and renewable energy access necessary for the countries' broad-based economic 
growth. 
 
16. 
Sri Lanka. Given the country’s recent high deficits, and its need to sustain its economic 
development  path,  its  high  dependence  on  oil  imports  could  be  very  costly  to  Sri  Lanka.  The 
country  partnership  strategy 16  identifies  opportunities  that  could  help  prevent  future  supply–
demand imbalances, such as the adoption of renewable energy and other environment-friendly 
alternative energy sources. To complement this effort, the strategy also supports the application 
of energy efficiency measures in all sectors. The private sector is recognized to be an important 
driver  in  realizing  these  opportunities,  while  the  public  sector  is  expected  to  lead  the  needed

actions  to  overcome  the  key  constraints  in  improving  the  regulatory  environment  for  clean 
energy investments in the country. 
 
17. 
Thailand.  Energy  sector  and  private  sector  development  are  likewise  priorities  for 
Thailand. Among the five key strategies behind the national development plan, as stated in the 
country partnership strategy,17 is economic restructuring for increased productivity, investment, 
and  competitiveness.  Infrastructure  development,  capital  market  development,  and  energy 
efficiency improvements, particularly new investments in energy security, are core elements of 
this strategy. The country’s operations business plan18 highlights the need for expanded private 
sector  operations,  and  for  ADB’s  assistance  with  cofinancing,  private  sector  participation,  and 
specialized expertise for complex projects. This private sector involvement will supplement the 
public  sector's  large  program  of  mainstreaming  energy  efficiency  measures  and  promoting 
energy conservation in country's municipal governments. 
 
Viet  Nam.  Viet Nam’s  country  operations  business  plan  for  2009–201119  emphasizes 
18. 
the need for new climate change and renewable energy interventions. ADB, through its public 
sector window, will also assist the government in promoting clean energy and expanding rural 
electrification,  particularly  to  households  in  underserved  areas.  Several  of  these  public  sector 
activities include the implementation of clean energy and power generation projects all over the 
country. The plan recognizes the role of the private sector in providing additional resources on 
top  of  public  sector  funding  for  energy  infrastructure—ultimately  strengthening  public–private 
partnership in energy sector development. 

4. 

Consistency with Sector Strategy 

ADB’s new Energy Policy20 defines the role of the private sector in securing the energy 
19. 
needs  of  the  region.  The  policy  encourages  private  sector  participation  (and  public–private 
partnership)  to  improve  energy  sector  efficiency  through  competition  and  an  increase  in 
investable  resources  in  DMCs.  ADB  and  other  multilateral  development  organizations  have 
poured capital into this sector through public sector loans and other financing mechanisms for 
clean  energy  projects.  However,  the  investment  has  been  insufficient  to  build  and  sustain  the 
increasingly energy-intensive infrastructure and economic activities. The private sector must fill 
the gap, by allocating financial resources and technical expertise for clean energy businesses in 
the  DMCs,  particularly  the  target  countries  in  the  GMS  and  South  Asia  (which  lag  far  behind 
DMCs such as the People’s Republic of China [PRC] and India in this regard).  

5. 

Lessons Learned from Previous Operations 

Key  recommendations  of  ADB’s  evaluation  study  of  the  energy  sector  in  the  GMS 21 
20. 
released in 2008 are to: (i) promote other energy investments besides power trading and focus 
more attention on clean energy investments, in line with ADB’s initiatives for energy efficiency 
and  climate  change;  and  (ii)  expand  cofinancing  by  leveraging  ADB’s  resources  to  mobilize 
financing  from  the  private  sector  and  other  development  partners.  A  recent,  separate 
independent  evaluation  of  ADB’s  GMS  program22  rated  it  successful  overall,  identifying  some 
lessons  that  are  relevant  to  the  program’s  next  phases  of  implementation.  These  lessons 
include a recognition that coordination within the GMS energy program and between energy and 
other sectors (e.g., the private sector) could still improve. Two relevant recommendations of this

would  include  private  sector  participation  in  infrastructure  development  and  would  strengthen

Key recommendations of ADB's evaluation study of private equity funds23, in addition to 
21. 
a  number  of  general  suggestions  (e.g.  enhancing  staffing,  risk  management  systems,  and 
portfolio management), included: (i) strengthening country programming arrangements so there 
is  better  coordination  in  development  of  the  nonbank  financial  sector,  and  (ii)  articulating  an 
operational strategy that sets out target countries and sectors. This project generates synergies 
between public sector efforts in the various target countries, and the private sector investments 
that will be made through the fund, and also aligns with ADB's focus (that has been articulated 
throughout recent funds operations) on underinvested countries and sectors.    

C. 

Development Impact 

1. 

Project Outputs and Outcome 

22. 
The key output of ADB’s investment will be the establishment of the fund itself, which will 
be  considered  successful  if  the  fund  raises  at  least  $80  million  within  1  year  after  the  initial 
close.24  Other  outputs  will  include  the  various  activities  of  the  fund  as  it  moves  through  the 
investment  process,  i.e.,  as  investment  opportunities  are  identified,  screened,  and  evaluated; 
financially  viable  investments  are  made;  the  portfolio  is  monitored  and  value  is  added  to  the 
investments made; and divestments from the investments yield a commercial return to the fund. 
These  outputs  will  increase  the  flow  of  funding  and  expertise  in  clean  energy  projects  in  the 
target  regions  (outcome)  through  the  fund’s  investment  in  at  least  10  clean  energy  and 
environment  projects  or  companies  by  2014,  and  the  fund  manager’s  ongoing  management 
advice to those investees. As a result, the sustainable energy sectors in the DMCs will develop 
over  time,  and  the  private  sector  will  contribute  more  to  the  clean  energy  and  environment 
sectors (impact).  

2. 

Impact 

23. 
As mentioned in para. 23, the ultimate development impact of the proposed investment 
will  be  sustainable  energy  development  in  ADB’s  DMCs,  particularly  in  the  target  countries  in 
the  GMS  and  South  Asia,  as  well  as  private  sector  development  in  the  clean  energy  and 
environment sectors. These objectives will be facilitated through the following channels: 

a. 

Sustainable Energy Security and Economic Development 

24. 
In light of ADB’s goal of securing the energy needs of its DMCs, the fund will invest in 
clean  energy  projects  to  augment  public  or  private  sector–led  projects,  thus  bridging  the  gap 
between  the  available  supply  of  and  actual  demand  for  energy  in  these  countries.  As 
sustainable  energy  supply  is  achieved  through  the  public  and  private  sector  initiatives, 
competition will result in more efficient power markets and more affordable power prices for the 
millions  of  industrial,  commercial,  and  domestic  end-users  in  the  region.  Access  to  affordable 
energy for these end-users could lead to more business opportunities and investments, and in 
turn to more jobs and higher living standards for the population.

b. 

Private Sector Participation and Development 

thus 

is  both  operationally  and  economically  viable, 

25. 
Unlike  private  investors  in  the  PRC  and  India,  private  investors  in  the  target  countries 
are often reluctant to invest in clean energy projects because of the inherent risks. The sector, 
as  a  result,  is  often  undercapitalized.  ADB’s  participation  in  the  fund  will  help  to  provide  a 
measure  of  confidence  to  the  private  sector  that  investing  in  the  clean  energy  sector  in  these 
DMCs 
inducing  more-active  and 
more-confident private sector participation.  
 
Besides investing in the growth and expansion of existing clean energy companies, the 
26. 
fund is also expected to invest in early-stage projects, resulting in local start-up companies and 
job creation that can help sustain employment in the region. 
 
The  Fund  will  provide  management  advice  to  entrepreneurial  companies  on  financial 
27. 
planning,  project  development,  business  expansion  strategies,  human  resource  development, 
technology,  environmental  and  social  issues,  and  the  implementation  of  international  best 
practices  in  corporate  governance,  thus  raising  the  quality  of  individual  companies.  As 
companies  in  the  industry  are  forced  to  compete  for  market  share  and  financing,  the  whole 
industry will gain in sophistication and efficiency. 

 

c. 

Climate Change Mitigation 

28. 
ADB has affirmed its strong support for efforts to mitigate and adapt to climate change. 
The  proposed  investment  in  the  fund  can  directly  and  indirectly  contribute  to  this  particular 
agenda,  particularly  on  the  mitigation  side.  The  clean  energy  projects  in  which  the  fund  will 
invest  will  substantially  reduce  GHG  emissions  in  the  target  countries  versus  the  baseline 
scenario of carbon-intensive energy projects that would otherwise be developed. 
 
ADB’s  technical  assistance  for  the  Regional  Review  of  the  Economics  of  Climate 
29. 
Change  in  Southeast  Asia25  gives  insights  into  the  significant  economic  costs  that  would  be 
incurred  if  nothing  is  done  to  combat  climate  change.  A  similar  study  is  being  done  for  South 
Asia (Regional Economics of Climate Change in South Asia, a subproject under ABD’s technical 
assistance for the Development Partnership Program for South Asia).26 Given the need to build 
a low-carbon and climate-resilient society, the prospective project investments of the fund can 
have  an  obvious  and  significant  role.  Once  clean  energy  projects  are  in  place  and  are 
commercially  viable,  the  countries  in  these  subregions  can  substantially  lower  their  carbon 
footprint  in  the  medium  to  long  term  by  investing  in  further  projects,  thereby  reducing  the 
economic costs associated with climate change. 

III. 

THE FINANCIAL INTERMEDIARY 

A. 

Ownership 

The  fund  manager  will  be  Dragon  Capital  Clean  Development  Investments  Ltd., 
30. 
incorporated in the British Virgin Islands. The fund manager is owned by Dragon Capital Group 
(Dragon), an integrated asset management company with a focus on Viet Nam’s capital markets. 
Established  in  1994,  Dragon  is  among  the  largest  and  most  experienced  asset  managers  in 
Viet Nam, with total assets in excess of $1 billion.

B. 

Governance Structure 

1. 

Management 

33. 
Dragon has put together an experienced management team for the fund. The investment 
team of the fund manager is composed of individuals whose backgrounds combine experience 
in project development, investment, deal origination, and clean energy technology.  

2. 

Corporate Governance 

The  fund  will  have  an  advisory  board,  comprising  certain  institutional  investors,  to 
34. 
represent the interests of the investors, supervise the fund’s operations, and advise and guide 
the fund manager. ADB will be represented on the advisory board.  

3. 

Risk Management 

35. 
The  fund  manager  will  manage  risk  through  its  investment  process,  which  involves 
several  layers  of  approval,  and  through  its  investment  committee,  which  is  composed 
predominantly  of  independent  members  with  extensive  experience  in  clean  energy  and 
investment management.  

C. 

Business Overview and Strategy 

1. 

Investment Objectives and Policies 

36. 
The  fund  aims  to  provide  investors  with  stable,  long-term  capital  growth  and  cash 
distributions  by  investing  in  clean  energy  and  environment  projects  in  the  target  countries  in 
GMS  and  South  Asia.  The  partnership  will  attempt  to  achieve  its  objective  by  making 
investments  that  meet  the  “triple  bottom  line”  principles  of  “people,  planet,  and  profit”—values 
that would require that each investment have  a positive impact on the environment and make 
contributions to sustainable development. The  embedding of environmental sustainability in its 
business  model  will  drive  the  fund  manager  to  comply  with  the  requirement  that  each 
investment  should:  (i)  meet  or  exceed  domestic  environmental  and  social  regulations  and 
requirements;  (ii)  demonstrate  a  significant  contribution  to  reductions  in  GHG  emissions, 
ozone-depleting  substances,  and  other  pollutants;  and  (iii)  comply  with  the  environmental  and 
social guidelines of ADB.  

                                                
 
27  The Bangkok office was established recently to assist in the operations of the fund. 

 

  

8 
 

2. 

Investment Strategy 

37. 
The target investment subsectors are categorized into three primary areas: (i) renewable 
energy  (including  energy  production  [hydro,  solar,  wind,  biomass,  biogas]  and  energy 
equipment); (ii) energy efficiency (including energy-efficient process [heat, sensors, combustion, 
insulation]  and  energy  efficiency  products);  and  (iii)  conservation  (including  natural  resource 
conservation, industrial wastewater and solid waste treatment, and recycling).  

IV. 

THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE 

A. 

ADB Intervention and Transaction Structure 

ADB proposes to make an equity investment of up to $15 million in the fund or 25% of 
38. 
the fund’s total share capital, whichever is less. ADB will not be the single-largest investor in the 
fund. The targeted fund size is $100 million, with a first closing of a minimum of $40 million. The 
fund  has  been  well  received  by  other  development  financial  institutions,  including  the  Belgian 
Investment Company for Developing Countries, the Finnish Fund for Industrial Cooperation, and 
the Netherlands Development Finance Company.  

B. 

Justification for ADB Assistance 

39. 
There are a number of justifications for ADB’s support of this investment. ADB’s primary 
value addition in this investment is its catalytic role in the fund-raising being undertaken by the 
fund, which should encourage private investors and other multilateral and bilateral development 
partners to bring in more capital to the fund. This will help to develop the capital markets in the 
region by filling the gap that currently exists vis-à-vis risk capital for clean energy projects. ADB 
has  also  been  instrumental  in  assisting  the  fund  manager  in  conceptualizing  the  fund  and  its 
clean energy investment strategy.  
 
40. 
Another important value addition of ADB’s investment in the fund is the guarantee that 
sustainable  development  issues  and  concerns  are  addressed  in  every  investee  project  of  the 
fund,  particularly  with  respect  to  balancing  the  varying  priorities  of  economic  development 
objectives,  environmental  protection,  and  social  equity 
the  different  DMCs.  ADB’s 
environmental and social safeguard policies and procedures will help to guide the fund at every 
step in ensuring the sustainability of its future clean energy projects. This is an important value 
addition, since the fund’s target countries frequently possess fragile and exploited environments 
as a result of prior uncontrolled industrial activity, as well as the possible existence of vulnerable 
communities  including  indigenous  groups  or  ethnic  minorities  who  may  be  adversely  affected, 
and to which ADB’s social safeguard policies and procedures may apply.  
 
41. 
Given the significant need for private investments in the target countries in the GMS and 
South  Asia,  ADB’s  intervention  through  the  fund  will  help  mobilize  capital  to  support  other 
private equity funds to pursue this path. It will help to develop a class of new fund managers and 
financial  professionals  in  the  sustainability  sectors  in  the  target  region’s  more  challenging 
economies. 
 
42. 
The fund, similar to others in which ADB invests, will make a direct contribution to private 
sector development. The fund will employ market-based mechanisms to develop profitable and 
sustainable enterprises in the sectors that need them the most. ADB’s contribution to this type 
of  initiative  helps  its  DMCs  to  implement  their  respective  country-specific  private  sector 
development strategies.

V. 

POLICY COMPLIANCE 

A. 

Environment and Social Safeguards 

43. 
ADB’s  investment  in  the  fund  is  classified  as  category  FI  under  ADB’s  Environment 
Policy (2002) and as category C under both ADB’s Involuntary Resettlement Policy (1995) and 
Policy on Indigenous Peoples (1998). The fund will be required to establish and implement an 
appropriate environmental and social management system (ESMS) for its investee companies 
to  meet  national  laws  and  ADB’s  requirements  in  the  countries  in  which  these  companies  are 
located. ADB will coordinate with the fund manager to ensure that the ESMS is adopted prior to 
disbursement for the first investment, and implemented in environmental and social safeguards 
due diligence, monitoring, and reporting.  

B. 

Anticorruption Policy 

44. 
The  fund  was  advised  of  ADB’s  Anticorruption  Policy  (1998,  as  amended  to  date)  and 
policy  relating  to  the  Combating  of  Money  Laundering  and  the  Financing  of  Terrorism  (2003). 
Consistent with its commitment to good governance, accountability, and transparency, ADB will 
require  the  fund  to  institute,  maintain,  and  comply  with  internal  procedures  and  controls 
following international best-practice standards for the purpose of preventing corruption or money 
laundering  activities  or  the  financing  of  terrorism,  and  covenant  with  ADB  to  refrain  from 
engaging  in  such  activities.  The  investment  documentation  between  ADB  and  the  fund  will 
further allow ADB to investigate any violation or potential violation of these undertakings. 
 
As  mentioned,  the  fund  manager  will  be  incorporated  in  the  British  Virgin  Islands,  an 
45. 
offshore  financial  center  (OFC)  and  common  location  of  incorporation  for  funds  and  fund 
managers. The fund itself will be incorporated in Guernsey, Channel Islands, another commonly 
used  OFC.  Incorporation  in  an  OFC  allows  the  fund  and  its  investors  to  avoid  excessive 
taxation, as a result of the British Virgin Islands’ own tax regulations and the tax treaties that it 
has  with  other  countries.  Having  undertaken  its  own  due  diligence  of  this  matter,  ADB  is 
satisfied  that  the  fund  will  not  be  used  for  cross-border  tax  evasion,  money  laundering,  or  the 
financing of terrorism. 

C. 

Assurances 

Following  the  approval  of  the  proposed  investment  by  ADB's  Board  of  Directors,  ADB 

46. 
will enter into suitable documentation, in a form and substance satisfactory to ADB. 

VI. 

RECOMMENDATION 

47. 
I  am  satisfied  that  the  proposed  equity  investment  would  comply  with  the  Articles  of 
Agreement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the 
investment  of  up  to  $15,000,000  to  the  Mekong  Brahmaputra  Clean  Development  Fund,  L.P. 
from  ADB’s  ordinary  capital  resources,  on  terms  and  conditions  as  are  substantially  in 
accordance with those set forth in this report and as may be reported to the Board.
